prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for switching my birth control without telling my mom
So I’m 17 and yesterday it was time for me to go get depo shot (every three months). I have been looking at the nexplanon implant (every 5 years) because I thought it would be more convenient and overall better. 

I brought up the implant with my mom and she told me to wait until I’m 18 (3 months from now) and she wouldn’t even talk to me as to why I wanted it. That was it. 

I went and during the appointment I asked if I could do the implant and they said they could do it for me and I went ahead and got it inserted (mom wasn’t there). When I told my mom she hung up the phone on me. She forgot about it and things were fine and when it was mentioned today she said she forgot about that and she was upset that I went and got it. I told her that it would be better for me to go ahead and get it now while I’m not working full time like I plan to be after I turn 18 in the summer and my arm can heal fine (I work retail and have to lift heavy cases and stuff).

She said she wanted to do ‘research on it’ and kept asking if I even knew the side effects which are no different that the depo shot.

I feel like she’s overreacting and mind you she has an IUD so I’m not too sure why she’s going so hard about it. What would’ve been the difference between now and 18? I’m not sure why she thinks I’m not allowed to make choices like these on my own. 

Also I’m not sexually active or anything and she knows that. I just wanted something more long term. 

AITA?
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

But in some places, minors can consent to certain medical treatments, especially related to reproductive health. I'm not sure about the exact laws here. Next, the mom's perspective. She wanted the author to wait until 18, maybe because of legal authority or concern about the author making a hasty decision. She also mentioned researching the side effects, which might indicate she felt the author wasn't fully informed. However, the author argues that the side effects are similar to the Depo shot, so maybe the mom's concerns are unfounded. Also, the mom has an IUD, so she's using a long-term method herself, which the author points out as contradictory.

The author's reasoning: they wanted a more convenient method, aren't currently sexually active, and wanted to get it done before starting a full-time job that might make healing harder. These seem valid points. The mom's reaction seems to be more about authority and possibly overreaction rather than the medical decision itself.

But the key issue here is consent. If the author didn't need parental consent for this procedure, then they might not be in the wrong. If they did, then maybe they are. But given that the clinic allowed it, maybe the law allows minors to consent to such procedures. Also, the author was proactive in making a decision about their own body, which is a valid argument for their side.

Considering all that, the author's actions might be justified if they had the legal right to make the decision. The mom's reaction could be seen as overstepping, especially since the author's reasons are valid and they're not engaging in risky behavior. The mom's insistence on waiting until 18 without a solid reason might not be fair.
